2.text:
What was meant by historians fifteen hundred
years ago when they wrote of kings and kingdoms?

22.text:
Today, most people around the world see the
British kingdom - the United Kingdom of Great

56.text:
Britain and Northern Ireland - as the super-kingdom,
its throne occupied by the super-royal, its

62.text:
inheritance the natural order of things. This
order is hardly questioned outside Britain,

68.text:
and not very much inside, now that Princess
Diana's character is better known, and she

73.text:
increasingly becomes an historical figure.
Even the outpouring of grief for her in 1997

80.text:
was hardly about getting rid of the kingdom
- for some, it was no more than jumping the

84.text:
succession to exclude Prince Charles - although
the worst opinion poll for him at the time

91.text:
was down to 64% in favour of his succeeding
his mother - a rating that an incumbent prime

98.text:
minister or American president would give
his right arm for.

103.text:
The word 'kingdom' is used in several ways
in the early Anglo-Saxon centuries. First,

108.text:
it is used of the Roman Empire, as in, 'and
Martianus and Valentinian succeeded to the

114.text:
kingdom,' a line quoted from the Anglo-Saxon
Chronicle in the last Episode. It is also

119.text:
used of Rome's successor state, the Eastern
Empire, based on Constantinople, from the

124.text:
fifth century. Finally, it is used of the
Western, or Holy Roman Empire, established

131.text:
by Charlemagne in 800, with its capital at
Aachen, western Germany.

137.text:
The three Roman empires have features we can
recognize as being organized government. All

142.text:
were continuous until their fall. Their kings
or emperors inherited written codes of law,

148.text:
to which they added, or they wrote their own
law codes. They ruled by writ, or by writing,

155.text:
so there were bureaucracies of literate men
to make imperial law effectual.

161.text:
Because law was written down, educated men
knew what was lawful and what was not, and

166.text:
the elements would have reached all society.
Indeed, the existence of established bureaucracies

173.text:
enabled government to function in those inevitable
periods when a hopeless king inherited the

178.text:
throne. The gathering of taxes was a daily
component of people's lives. The royal authority

184.text:
was transmitted by a clear descent either
in a family, or by marriage into a ruling

190.text:
family, and exercised by what are sometimes
called today apparachiks, who had a vested

195.text:
interest in the continuity of their jobs and
power, as such people still do.

201.text:
There were exceptions. An important one was
Justinian, Emperor of the East at Constantinople,

207.text:
in the sixth century. He re-conquered much
of Italy and North Africa, produced a law

212.text:
code, reformed his Church, and is magnificently
commemorated with his wife Theodora in two

218.text:
mosaic reliefs at Ravenna, his capital in
Italy. In the West, there is Charlemagne himself,

225.text:
who created the Holy Roman Empire by continuing
conquests begun by his father. He was the

231.text:
son of Pippin the Short, who had been mayor
of the palace to the Merovingian kings of

235.text:
the Franks, later the French. For the previous
century, the Merovingian family had feuded,

241.text:
and the mayor of the palace became the power
in the land. Charles Martel, whom we met in

247.text:
Episode Three as the victor of Poitiers, against
the Muslims, in 732, was mayor of the palace.

256.text:
His son Pippin deposed Childeric III, the
last Merovingian king of the Franks.

262.text:
What Charlemagne's father Pippin lacked in
family descent, he got from Rome when Pope

267.text:
Zacharias gave his blessing to regime change,
to employ the modern expression Ever practical,

275.text:
Rome supported the power on the ground, and
Pippin became king. All of these rulers were

281.text:
also protectors of, and were protected by,
a Christian Church, one of whose tenets was

287.text:
Christ's exhortation to 'render unto Caesar
that which is Caesar's' - although the predicate,

293.text:
'and unto God that which is God's,' was usually
forgotten in the dynastic cut and thrust of

298.text:
politics. Custom, respect, and even tyranny
tend to support religion. Nothing much changes.

309.text:
For dynasties today read political families
and parties, media and banking empires, or

314.text:
the dynasties of stage and screen, where aristocracies
thrive, and whose individual names easily

321.text:
drop off the tongue in our modern world. In
the early centuries AD, emperors succeeded

328.text:
to great empires and cities, and could mobilize
money and labour to beautify them in brick

333.text:
and carved stone and fabulous interiors over
many years. Charlemagne began at Aachen, and

340.text:
we are left, more than twelve hundred years
later, with the remains of the symbols of

345.text:
his power and magnificence. Display is a critical
attribute of monarchy.

352.text:
Kingdom is also used indiscriminately in chronicles
because it was not always easy to find the

357.text:
correct word for a warlord's sphere of authority.
So when the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle says that

364.text:
'Hengest and Aesc his son succeeded to the
kingdom,' it cannot mean that they succeeded

369.text:
to anything remotely as organized as the Roman
Empire had been when Britannia was a province,

375.text:
or as organized as the kingdom of Wessex had
become by King Alfred's death in 899. When

382.text:
the Romans left Britannia at the end of the
fourth century, the remains of the tax system

387.text:
would have died instantly, the rule of written
law would have atrophied over perhaps a longer

392.text:
period, and the better off Romano-Britons
would have repaired to their villas to become

398.text:
the sitting ducks of warlords, who led the
conquest of the island At the Edge of the

405.text:
Kingdom seems to have been a convenient term
that everyone would have understood, and was

410.text:
probably applied to any area under the domination
of a leader of a band of armed men, whose

415.text:
chief was usually referred to as a 'king.'
Similarly, 'princes of the Angle race' are

421.text:
unlikely to have had the same meaning in the
fifth century as at the end of the ninth,

426.text:
when the Chronicle was begun, and when being
'of the Blood' had become legally relevant

431.text:
to the succession. Even before King Alfred's
reign, male members of the king's family were

437.text:
called 'aethlings' - what we might call 'royal
highnesses' - literally, they were 'throne-worthy.'

445.text:
Alfred himself was the youngest of King Aethelwulf's
four sons, each of whom in order of seniority

456.text:
Royalty in the sense of lawful descent was
well known and cherished among the pagan German

462.text:
incomers of the fifth and sixth centuries,
but leadership was also based on whether one

467.text:
was a successful warlord. Within a chieftain's
family, there would very likely have been

473.text:
a member or two who was ready to fill a vacancy
- or even to create one.

479.text:
As the chronicler, William of Malmesbury,
puts it: 'sedition always has adherents.'

485.text:
The literature of the German Romantic movement,
from the 1780s, harked back to this ancient

490.text:
past, and was disseminated to all through
Wagnerian opera. We also come across men described

497.text:
as kings of the Hwicca people in Warwickshire
and Worcestershire, of Lindsey, in Lincolnshire,

503.text:
of Elmet, in west Yorkshire. We shall meet
Guthrum, King Alfred's mortal Viking enemy,

508.text:
who is called king, but it is hard to say
whether he was a real king - in a period when

513.text: kingship was becoming more than merely a warlord.

518.text:
Perhaps another test of an established monarchy
in these early centuries after Rome is from

522.text:
whom their kings were descended and whom they
married. The first Christian king of Kent,

528.text:
Aethelberht, had married Bertha, daughter
of the Christian King Charibert, of the Franks.

535.text:
A power struggle in Wessex at the end of the
eighth century obliged the future King Ecgberht

541.text:
to seek protection at Charlemagne's court
in Germany, where he married the Emperor's

546.text:
great niece Raedburh. Ecgberht eventually
succeeded to Wessex in 802 and reigned until

555.text:
In Blood Royal, Charles Mosley describes this
king as ancestor of every royal and princely

560.text:
house in Europe - surely, genealogy was the
crucial element that made true kingship. Bede

567.text:
himself seems not always to be of one mind
on whether an area was a kingdom or a province:

572.text:
he often speaks of his own Northumbria as
a province. The opening annals of the Winchester

578.text:
version of the Chronicle tell us other things
about Britain at this time of flux.

584.text:
The Britons, under Vortigern, were experiencing
challenges to their authority from the Picts

589.text:
of Caledonia (modern Scotland). Rome, the
former imperial power, was unable to help

595.text:
him and Vortigern turned to the Angles in
southern Denmark for assistance. The last

601.text:
of the regular relief of Roman garrisons in
Britain took place in about 381, and the Chronicle

607.text:
suggests that a power vacuum was left behind.
We do not know how far Vortigern's authority

613.text:
ran, but possibly as far south as Kent because
this is where Hengest and Horsa are said to

619.text:
have landed in 449. Remember, they had come
at first to help the British king. There are

625.text:
likely to have been British leaders in other
parts of the country, and Vortigern may have

630.text:
enjoyed a kind of overlordship of the former
Roman province.

635.text:
At first, the Anglo-Saxons were helpful against
the Picts, but they soon turned against their

640.text:
British hosts, describing them as 'worthless'
and the land as excellent. Reinforcements

646.text:
were sent for from Angeln, north Germany,
and Vortigern must have been overthrown in

651.text:
a battle at Aylesford, Kent, against the Anglo-Saxons
because Hengest and Aesc succeeded to the

657.text:
kingdom. We know that Horsa was killed, but
there is no mention of the death of Vortigern,

663.text: who may also have died at about the same time.

666.text:
Two years later, the Britons abandoned Kent,
after a battle at Crayford, where four thousand

672.text:
were killed, and they withdrew to London.
The story of the arrival of Hengest and Horsa

677.text:
in the Chronicle is thought to have been taken
from Bede who gives us the traditional displacement

683.text:
of the German settlers around the England:
These newcomers were from the three most formidable

688.text:
races of Germany, the Saxons, Angles, and
Jutes.

694.text:
From the Jutes are descended the people of
Kent and the Isle of Wight and those of the

698.text:
province of the West Saxons opposite the Isle
of Wight who are called Jutes to this day.

703.text:
From the Saxons - that is the country now
known as the land of the Old Saxons - came

708.text:
the East, South, and West Saxons. And from
the Angles - that is the country known as

714.text:
Angulus, which lies between the provinces
of the Jutes and Saxons and is said to remain

719.text:
unpopulated to this day - are descended the
East and Middle Saxons, the Mercians, all

725.text:
the Northumbrian stock (that is those people
living north of the river Humber), and other

732.text:
Their first chieftains are said to have been
the brothers Hengest and Horsa. The latter

737.text:
was subsequently killed in battle against
the Britons, and was buried in East Kent,

742.text:
where the monument bearing his name still
stands. They were the sons of Wictgils, whose

747.text:
father was Witta, whose father was Wecta,
son of Woden, from whose stock sprang the

753.text:
royal house of many provinces. Although Bede's
disposition of the invaders has been attacked

758.text:
over the years, it has proved very durable.
There are many stories from the fifth and

764.text:
sixth centuries which speak of persistent
invasions of England. Some tell how the invaders

769.text:
fell out and fought one another, and as late
as the eighth century, Bede despairs that

774.text:
the kingdoms within England, particularly
his own Northumbria, were never weaker than

779.text: when family members fought one another.

783.text:
A nation speaks one language and we learn
from the Peterborough manuscript of the Anglo-Saxon

789.text:
Chronicle that the languages of Britain were
English, British, Welsh, Scottish, Pictish,

797.text:
and Book Language. Book Language meant Latin.
Cornish or West Welsh may also have been a

804.text:
spoken language. Since this list is taken
from Bede, it seems likely that these languages

810.text:
were those commonly spoken in different areas
of Britain in the first quarter of the eighth

818.text:
Perhaps English had become the prevailing
spoken language in the lands of the Anglo-Saxons

823.text:
by the end of the ninth century when the Chronicle
was begun. This theme continues in the next

830.text:
Episode with the 'naming' of England. Some
of the symbols of nationhood that originated

835.text:
in our period and have been adapted into our
modern age might be unexpected.
